https://prez.dev/description.@value: A categorization of disciplines or topics that the broad field of Earth science can be subdivided into, i.e. a listing of the Fields of Research, or subjects, to which a geoscience dataset, publication, observation/activity, or entity pertains. The vocabulary also contains relevant disciplines that intersect with the various Earth science fields, such as biological sciences and built environment and design, as well as entries related to collection and heritage management. Notations included are those from the 2020 ANZSRC listing (see History Note) or in common use in the geoscience community.

The study of the physical and chemical properties of rocks in relation to their interaction with fluids. A major application of petrophysics is in studying reservoirs for the hydrocarbon industry (especially the distribution of the pore system and its contained hydrocarbons and water).

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The study of the physical and mechanical properties of rocks. Petrophysics focuses on how the microstructure of porous geological materials affects their mechanical, electrical, thermal, fluid flow, and sonic properties. Rock mechanics considers the mechanical or geomechanical properties of rocks, including reservoir strength, elastic properties, hardness, ultrasonic behaviour, index characteristics, and in situ stresses.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Compiled by Geological Survey of Western Australia from multiple sources.

https://prez.dev/description.@value: The study of the physical and mechanical properties of rocks. Petrophysics focuses on how the microstructure of porous geological materials affects their mechanical, electrical, thermal, fluid flow, and sonic properties. Rock mechanics considers the mechanical or geomechanical properties of rocks, including reservoir strength, elastic properties, hardness, ultrasonic behaviour, index characteristics, and in situ stresses.

A theoretical and applied science of the physical behaviour of rocks and rock masses. In relation to geology, it is the branch of mechanics concerned with the response of rock and rock masses to the force fields of their physical environment.
